Award.AwardTitle: The SEaRCH: Towards the Development of a STEM Education Research Consortium at HBCUs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) provides support to undertake an institutional self-analysis in preparation for a Broadening Participation Research Center. Broadening Participation Research Centers are expected to serve as national hubs for the rigorous study and broad dissemination of the critical pedagogies and culturally sensitive interventions that contribute to the success of HBCUs in educating African American science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) undergraduates. This project is a collaborative effort between the initial members of an education research consortium: Tennessee State University, Prairie View A&M University, Morgan State University, North Carolina A&T State University, and Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University. The consortium of schools and team of researchers will work to plan research activities that will lead to the formation of a research center that delineates which individual factors, environmental factors, institutional practices, procedures, and policies are most effective in ensuring that students successfully complete STEM degrees at HBCUs.

Activities of this project include: implementating a strategic planning framework built upon the broadening participation education research expertise of the collaborating institutions involved in the development of an expanded education research consortium of HBCUs; using evidence-based strategies to generate a high-quality plan for the research thrusts and research methodologies of the resulting center; and addressing the gap in the literature regarding STEM education research results, practices and policies pertinent to student persistence and graduation at HBCUs. The project will be guided by an on-going evaluation and an external advisory committee.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This consortium of schools and team of researchers have worked collectively, collaboratively, and cooperatively to form a plan for a research center that delineated which individual factors, environmental factors, institutional practices, procedures, and policies were helpful and those that are most effective in ensuring that students successfully complete STEM degrees. Also, pilot research data was collected from more than 600 faculty and students representing 4 HBCUs regarding the persistence of underrepresented students in STEM fields. Results of this research have significantly contributed to increasing the persistence of STEM majors at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and has thus contributed to the development of a diverse future STEM workforce.

The results obtained, products produced, and workshops/training developed from this project will support the success of HBCUs, students and faculty/administrators involved in STEM programs. The involvement of various institutions has fostered the rapid dissemination of key information for the improvement of student persistence, individual factors, environmental factors, institutional practices, procedures, and policies.

The work activities of this pilot project focused on broadening participation and guaranteeing success for students completing STEM degrees at Historically Black Colleges and Universities will ultimately increase the middle class in America and shift the demographics and socio-economic factors involving underrepresented groups in our society. The cultural considerations of this project aimed to impact the future workforce of the nation creating a cycle of success and equity to advance STEM opportunities for all members of society.  The focus on institutional climate and cultural intersectionality have ensured the project has worked to break barriers for success across all fields.
